Author: smalls#0439
Content:
According to the npm article tweeted by @KomodoPlatform, the exploit was accomplished by having the AgamaApp transmit a user's private keys to the attacker when the wallet is opened. Note, they have a demo video you can watch.

With that in mind, how did the dev team sweep all of the coins from wallets that haven't been opened? I personally had not opened my wallet in 3 weeks, yet my funds were swept to the "safe" wallet. How is that possible without another backdoor that the dev team was sitting on?

Second, how are they going to verify ownership of the swept funds? Right now they are only asking for email-coin-address-amount-txid I assume they will ask for the seed/keys to verify ownership before dispersing funds. But, if the attacker has the keys to wallets that were swept, can't the hacker just claim the swept funds by using multiple email addresses?

https://blog.npmjs.org/post/185397814280/plot-to-steal-cryptocurrency-foiled-by-the-npm

Author: smalls#0439
Content:
From the npm article: "  Here is a brief demonstration showing the Agama wallet sending my wallet seed to a remote server.

    After launching the wallet application on the left, you see a request to on the right which downloads the second stage payload. Once we enter in our wallet seed you will see another request to that remote server successfully stealing our wallet seed."

Author: jeffjam#9765
Content: Because the issues goes back more than 3 weeks.

Author: smalls#0439
Content: And if the attacker has my keys and claims my funds, how is the team going to know which one of us to send the coins to?

Author: jeffjam#9765
Content: Also think about that there will certainly be some unclaimed funds.
